Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: This action arises under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, specifically Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, governing a landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a719 and \u00a721.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the **Cambridge District Court** pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and §21, as the rental premises are located within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 93A.proposition: The Defendant’s failure to mitigate demonstrates disregard for Plaintiff’s rights and obligations under **G.L. c. 93A** may also inform the assessment of reasonableness, see **Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991)**, though this complaint asserts only quiet enjoyment.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under **Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982)**, a landlord is liable under G.L. c. 186, §14 for acts or omissions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s enjoyment, regardless of the landlord’s intent.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court expressly interprets G.L. c. 186, §14 to not require proof that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. It holds that malicious intent is unnecessary and that, at minimum, reckless conduct that directly or indirectly interferes with quiet enjoyment suffices for liability. Although the opinion does not go so far as to impose strict liability for all “acts or omissions,” it clearly rejects an intent requirement and grounds liability on substantial interference rather than subjective purpose, which is materially consistent with the proposition as stated.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Second, Gem contends that § 14 prohibits only intentional conduct by a landlord. As we noted earlier, the jury did not find that Gem intended to harm Solomon. It did find, however, that Gem acted recklessly. … Our analysis of the language and history of § 14, however, leads us to conclude that malicious intent is not necessary, and that the statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct such as Gem’s.… Nor must the tenant prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights, at least as long as the landlord’s conduct was reckless.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: In **Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977)**, the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord may be liable for noise disturbances caused by third parties when the landlord could reasonably have foreseen and controlled the interference.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlords are responsible for the noise disturbances from the lounge, even though caused by third parties, because those disturbances were the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ leasing decision and because the landlords had the right and ability to control the objectionable conditions. The court emphasizes both foreseeability (the potential threat was apparent) and control (as a matter of law the landlords had a right to control the noise) as the bases for liability and for finding a breach of quiet enjoyment/constructive eviction.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “The judge was warranted in ruling that the landlords had it within their control to correct the condition which caused the tenants to vacate their apartments. The landlords introduced a commercial activity into an area where they leased premises for residential purposes… The potential threat to the occupants of the nearby apartments was apparent in the circumstances… We conclude that, as matter of law, the landlords had a right to control the objectionable noise coming from the lounge… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did… the landlords could control the actions at the lounge….”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that even temporary interferences may constitute violations if they are substantial in nature and impact, see **Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)**.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that failure to provide heat during the heating season is a serious impairment and a breach of quiet enjoyment, but it does not discuss the duration of the interference or draw any distinction between temporary versus ongoing interferences. The proposition about “even temporary interferences” being actionable is not addressed or articulated as a legal principle in this case, so citing Lowery for that specific temporal point overstates what the decision says.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Similar findings have been made where renovation-related dust, vibration, and noise deprived tenants of peaceful occupancy (see **Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)**).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns loss of heat and hot water and the resulting breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement. It does not involve or discuss renovation-related dust, vibration, or noise, nor deprivation of peaceful occupancy due to such renovation activities. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about renovation-related disturbances depriving tenants of peaceful occupancy.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Furthermore, from time to time, the apartment was without adequate hot water. These failures continued sporadically through June, 1977. … He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability.”

Winchester v. O'Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (192.proposition: Under Massachusetts case law, including **Simon v. Solomon, supra**, and **Winchester v. O'Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (1929)**, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached where a landlord’s acts or omissions substantially disturb the tenant’s comfort, repose, or enjoyment of the leased premises.
Winchester v. O'Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (192.support_reasoning: The court expressly recognizes that a lease carries an implied obligation that the lessor refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises, and finds that the landlord’s authorized construction activities caused a “substantial and continued interference” with the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment. Although the court analyzes overlapping theories (nuisance, trespass, implied covenant), it makes clear that the same acts can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment where they substantially interfere with the tenant’s peaceful and comfortable use of the premises. This aligns with the proposition that substantial disturbance of comfort, repose, or enjoyment can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Winchester v. O'Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (192.relevant_excerpt: “The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… If a landlord authorizes acts to be done which cause substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises… the landlord is liable therefor… It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises and appurtenant rights by the acts done or authorized by the defendants… The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant….”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered loss, distress, inconvenience, and inability to fully use the premises as a dwelling, entitling him to damages under G.L. c. 186, §14, as interpreted in **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)**.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that, if tenants are unable to use common areas (streets, sidewalks, parking lots, recreation areas) due to drug activity and the landlord has failed to take reasonable measures within its control, this constitutes a serious interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14, entitling tenants to judgment and statutory remedies. That directly aligns with the proposition that loss, distress, inconvenience, and inability to fully use the premises as a dwelling can support damages under §14 as interpreted in this case.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises… If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action… then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: The Defendant’s failure to mitigate demonstrates disregard for Plaintiff’s rights and obligations under **G.L. c. 93A** may also inform the assessment of reasonableness, see **Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991)**, though this complaint asserts only quiet enjoyment.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a landlord’s extensive sanitary code violations, emotional distress, warranty of habitability, and G.L. c. 93A liability, including treble damages, but it does not discuss a defendant’s failure to mitigate or use such a failure as evidence of disregard for a tenant’s rights. Nor does it tie any concept of mitigation to assessing the reasonableness of conduct under c. 93A or under the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, Haddad v. Gonzalez does not support the specific mitigation-based proposition for which it is cited.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt:
On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries as a consequence of Haddad's unfair and deceptive trade practices: emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability.
...
We conclude that, in appropriate circumstances, tenants may recover multiple damages for the intentional infliction of emotional distress under c. 93A.

Joyce v. Hickey, 337 Mass. 118 (1958).proposition: As further precedent, see **Joyce v. Hickey, 337 Mass. 118 (1958)** (recognizing landlord’s liability for interference with tenant’s beneficial use), **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997)** (holding landlord responsible for failure to maintain habitable conditions), and **Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988)** (requiring compensation for breach of quiet enjoyment).
Joyce v. Hickey, 337 Mass. 118 (1958).support_reasoning: Joyce v. Hickey is a tort action for false arrest/false imprisonment against a probate judge, focusing on judicial immunity and jurisdiction to punish for contempt. It does not involve a landlord-tenant relationship, habitability, quiet enjoyment, or interference with a tenant’s beneficial use of leased premises. Accordingly, it provides no authority for landlord liability or quiet enjoyment principles and is mis-cited for that proposition.
Joyce v. Hickey, 337 Mass. 118 (1958).relevant_excerpt: “In this action of tort for false arrest and false imprisonment… The defendant is judge of the Probate Court for Norfolk County… ‘It is a principle… that every judge… is exempt from liability to an action for any judgment or decision rendered in the exercise of jurisdiction vested in him by law.’ … In view of the broad allegations of fact in counts 1 and 2, it was error to sustain the demurrer to those counts.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: As further precedent, see **Joyce v. Hickey, 337 Mass. 118 (1958)** (recognizing landlord’s liability for interference with tenant’s beneficial use), **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997)** (holding landlord responsible for failure to maintain habitable conditions), and **Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988)** (requiring compensation for breach of quiet enjoyment).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The proposition characterizes Al‑Ziab as “holding landlord responsible for failure to maintain habitable conditions.” In this opinion, the SJC holds that a bare statutory lead‑paint violation does not, by itself, constitute a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, and that at least negligent conduct with notice is required. The case thus limits, rather than broadly affirms, landlord liability under the quiet enjoyment statute and does not stand as general precedent that landlords are responsible for failure to maintain habitable conditions per se.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988).proposition: As further precedent, see **Joyce v. Hickey, 337 Mass. 118 (1958)** (recognizing landlord’s liability for interference with tenant’s beneficial use), **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997)** (holding landlord responsible for failure to maintain habitable conditions), and **Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988)** (requiring compensation for breach of quiet enjoyment).
Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988).support_reasoning: The proposition cites Manzaro for “requiring compensation for breach of quiet enjoyment.” In this case, the SJC affirms the Housing Court’s award of three months’ rent as damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14, for the landlord’s interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment caused by prolonged ringing of smoke alarms. The opinion explicitly recognizes liability and monetary damages for a breach of quiet enjoyment, so it supports the proposition, even though it does not create the doctrine but applies it to the facts.
Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880 (1988).relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that…the landlord’s failure to silence the smoke alarms in a timely manner was an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises (in violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14). He awarded her three months’ rent… We cannot say the judge’s conclusion to award damages under § 14 was wrong… The ringing for a day of an alarm…cannot be said as a matter of law never to be sufficient interference to justify relief under § 14.”
